meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just wanted to quickly add that so there are thermodynamically downhill routes and there are thermodynamically uphill routes because CO2 is inherently doesn't have a lot of energy associated with it. It's the lowest carbon state, right? So if you want to take CO2 and put it in its lowest form, then the most logical pathway for that, at least what is in our consciousness at this point, is that of magnesium or calcium carbonate. It's an inorganic carbonate. And then if you actually want to take the CO2 and then if you want to upcycle it towards to a fuel, then the intermediate there, you'll need to identify it. It's typically carbon monoxide or maybe even a formate. So then the question becomes you can get to a CO, you can get to a formate, but once you have that, how do you get from there to your end goal, which could be a fuel, a polymer, or a product of some kind. And if you have a CO2 molecule, if you want to get it to being in its inorganic carbonate state, what are some of the least energetically intensive pathways to get there?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Greeshma Gadikota
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I think to that point, really the the end value and the customer base for this product matters, right? I mean if you're proposing to take CO2 and produce methane, it's going to be it's going to be very, very challenging to compete with shale gas and shale gas prices are, you know, really, really low. So that may not be the best route. So there might be other routes. And so what I'm trying to say is that some awareness of the market, some awareness of fit with the existing landscape, I think is important to consider in the context of particularly utilization. And another less explored route is industrial decarbonization. So there's a way for us to couple carbon negative CO2 utilization with trying to decarbonize the steel industry, cement industry. Uh that might also be another pathway. Also pathways to produce fertilizer, right? That require both nitrogen and hydrogen, right? Those could be pathways in which we could uh incorporate carbon negative CO2 utilization. So I think there there are ways in which this theme can get incorporated into a lot of industrial processes, I think.
